requirements:
Basic To-Do List Website Requirements
User Interface:

Simple input field to add new tasks quickly.

List display area showing tasks clearly.

Checkboxes or toggles to mark tasks as completed.

Edit and delete options for existing tasks.

Responsive design for use on both desktop and mobile devices.

Task Management:

Ability to add, edit, and delete tasks.

Mark tasks as complete or incomplete.

Option to prioritize or categorize tasks.

Save tasks persistently (local storage or backend database).

User Experience:

Clear visual differentiation between completed and pending tasks.

Easy navigation and intuitive controls.

Option to reorder tasks by drag and drop or priority.

Technical Requirements:

Responsive front-end using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

Optional backend for user authentication and task storage (using database).

Cross-browser compatibility.

Performance optimized for fast load and smooth interactions.

functional_requirements.description: Users must be able to add new tasks to their to-do list.
acceptance_criteria: An input field is available for entering task descriptions.
Pressing 'Enter' or clicking an 'Add' button adds the task to the list.
The input field is cleared after a task is added.

functional_requirements.description: Users must be able to view all their tasks.
acceptance_criteria: All added tasks are displayed in a list format.
Each task shows its description and a control for completion.

functional_requirements.description: Users must be able to mark tasks as completed.
acceptance_criteria: Each task has a checkbox or a similar control to mark it as complete.
Completed tasks are visually distinguished from pending tasks (e.g., strikethrough text).
Users can toggle the completion status of a task.

functional_requirements.description: Users should be able to edit the description of existing tasks.
acceptance_criteria: An 'Edit' button or icon is available for each task.
Clicking 'Edit' makes the task description editable in-line.
Users can save the changes to the task description.

functional_requirements.description: Users must be able to delete tasks from the list.
acceptance_criteria: A 'Delete' button or icon is available for each task.
Clicking 'Delete' removes the task from the list.

functional_requirements.description: Task data must persist between browser sessions.
acceptance_criteria: Tasks are saved automatically to the browser's local storage.
When the user reopens or refreshes the application, their tasks are reloaded.

functional_requirements.description: Users should be able to reorder tasks.
acceptance_criteria: Users can drag and drop tasks to change their order in the list.

non_functional_requirements.description: The application should load quickly and respond to user interactions without noticeable delay.
metrics: Initial page load time under 2 seconds.
UI updates (add, delete, edit) should complete in under 200ms.

non_functional_requirements.description: The user interface must be intuitive and easy to use for non-technical users.
metrics: A new user can add and complete a task within 1 minute without instructions.
All interactive elements have clear visual feedback (hover states, focus rings).

non_functional_requirements.description: The web application must be compatible with the latest versions of major web browsers.
metrics: The application renders and functions correctly on the latest two versions of Chrome, Firefox, Safari, and Edge.

non_functional_requirements.description: The application's layout must adapt to different screen sizes, providing a good user experience on both desktop and mobile devices.
metrics: The layout is usable and aesthetically pleasing on screen widths from 320px (mobile) to 1920px (desktop).
All functionality is accessible via touch on mobile devices.

risks: Scope Creep: Adding features beyond the initial requirements (e.g., user accounts, task sharing) could significantly delay the project.
Data Persistence Limitations: Using local storage means data is tied to a single browser and can be lost if the user clears their cache.
UI/UX Complexity: Implementing a smooth drag-and-drop experience can be more time-consuming than anticipated.
Cross-Browser Compatibility: Minor CSS or JavaScript inconsistencies across different browsers may require extra debugging time.
assumptions: The initial version will use the browser's local storage for data persistence, not a backend database.
User authentication and multi-user support are out of scope for the initial version.
The design will be simple and functional, without the need for complex custom graphics or animations.
